Title:
Observations on Texas Hypoxylons (Hypoxylaceae), including
two new Hypoxylon species and widespread environmental isolates of H.
croceum identified by a polyphasic approach
Keywords:
Ascomycota, chemotaxonomy, multigene phylogeny, taxonomy,
Xylariales, new species
Abstract:
Two new species of Hypoxylon from Texas were identified
and described based on morphological, multigene phylogenetic (ITS 
internal transcribed spacer region of ribosomal DNA, LSU  large subunit
of ribosomal DNA, RPB2  second largest subunit of the DNA-directed RNA
polymerase II, TUB  β-tubulin) and chemotaxonomic data. Hypoxylon
olivaceopigmentum is characterized by its pulvinate to glomerate
stromata, olivaceous KOH-extractable pigments, equilateral ascospores
and indehiscent perispore. Hypoxylon texensis can be distinguished from
morphologically similar species by its rust to dark brick
KOH-extractable pigments and its chemical profile. Updated descriptions
and comprehensive illustration with detailed information on the
diagnostic features of H. croceum, H. fendleri and H. perforatum are
provided. Sequence searches using the ITS sequence of H. croceum
revealed that the species is a widespread endophyte and endolichenic
fungus with a broad host range in the southeastern USA. In addition,
Nodulisporium hinnuleum was determined to be a synonym of H. croceum.
The multi-locus phylogenetic reconstruction of Hypoxylon supported the
status of the new species and broadened the knowledge about intergeneric
relationships and the identities of environmental isolates.
